courseMeetingStructure.attendance: Student success strongly correlated with regular attendance
courseMeetingStructure.sicknessPolicy: Students with fever, cough, shortness of breath, chills, muscle pain, sore throat, or loss of taste/smell should not attend; work with instructor to develop study plan

exceptionsToPrerequisites: Any exceptions must be approved by instructor

requiredMaterials.title: Munson, Young, and Okiishi's Fundamentals of Fluid Mechanics
requiredMaterials.format: Electronic or hard copy available; must be legal paid version
requiredMaterials.note: Some assigned problems have 'R' number (e.g., 5.1.3R) not in all printed versions; located on Learning Suite

requiredMaterials.title: ME EN 312 Course Packet
requiredMaterials.author: D. Maynes
requiredMaterials.requirement: Bring to each class session; includes examples worked in class

courseOverview: The study of fluid mechanics is exciting and insightful into phenomena in the world around us. Rigorous and mathematically intensive, utilizing multivariable calculus, differential equations, and linear algebra. Approach involves class discussions, text readings, problem-solving, special projects, and hands-on laboratory experiences.
timeExpectation: For each hour in class, expect to spend 2 hours outside of class on the subject. More time required for excellence.
courseObjectives: Provide understanding and ability to mathematically model fluid dynamics phenomena with competencies in 10 core topics.

coreTopics.competencies: Understand viscosity as fluid property and compute shear stress in Newtonian fluids; understand surface tension and cavitation
Understand pressure variation in static gas or liquid; compute hydrostatic forces and moments
Evaluate local, convective, and total acceleration; understand pressure distributions; appropriately apply Bernoulli's principle and recognize limitations
Apply integral form for steady and unsteady flow; recognize and utilize differential form of conservation of mass

Apply integral form of linear momentum principle; apply global force/momentum balances for stationary and constant velocity frames; recognize Navier-Stokes equations and solve for simplified viscous flows
Determine appropriate dimensionless variables; predict prototype behavior based on similitude; understand pitfalls of modeling
Understand mechanical energy equation and apply to laminar and turbulent flow with minor and major losses through pipe networks

coreTopics.topic: Velocity Distributions, Form Drag and Flow Separation
coreTopics.competencies: Model velocity distributions in flat plate boundary layers; predict skin friction drag; understand flow separation and impact on total drag
Utilize fluid dynamics principles to analyze and solve real-world flow phenomena; use 5 Ps problem definition and SAFER problem-solving techniques
Present results graphically with dimensionless variables; effectively communicate results

homework.purpose: Solidify principles for mastery of topics

types.sources: Munson text on Learning Suite Content tab
types.solution: Abbreviated SAFER method on paper of choice
types.collaboration: Encouraged as long as all contribute equally; copying not acceptable
types.assessment: Assessment on Learning Suite for each set

types.method: Complete SAFER method with problem-solving template
types.grading: Significant portion based on professional nature of solution; all graded and returned

homework.latePolicy: Accepted until 5:00 p.m. Thursday (day after due) with 15% penalty

reading.requirement: Reading of assigned material expected before class
reading.benefit: Increases exposure and prompts questions and class discussion
reading.schedule: Reading for each lecture shown on Learning Suite

lectures.coverage: Much information covered in class not in text and vice versa
lectures.expectation: Active participation and being well-versed in text essential

labsAndSpecialProblems.types: Real-world problem, do-at-home experiment, laboratory exercise, or special problem
labsAndSpecialProblems.deliverables: Due date and specifications given when assigned

quizzes.frequency: Approximately 10-12 in-class quizzes, generally at least one per week
quizzes.content: Conceptual questions from text, lecture, homework, videos, and laboratory
quizzes.identifier: No name on quiz; use chosen 4-digit identifier
quizzes.registration: Choose identifier by completing extra-credit quiz assignment due Friday September 5th
quizzes.pickup: Returned quizzes in Return Work box, south hallway, 3rd floor EB

exams.schedule: Two mid-term exams and comprehensive final exam
exams.materials: Equation sheet provided plus any relevant needed information

grading.finalExamReplacement: If final exam score > lowest midterm or composite quiz score, final replaces that score
grading.allA: If everyone scores 90-100 range, all receive A's
grading.curving: May curve if class average below 80%

citizenship.overview: Expected to adhere to honor code; academic dishonesty justifies failing grade
goodCitizenship: Respectfully addressing classmates, TA, and professor
badCitizenship: Talking or texting with others during lecture
citizenship.record: Citizenship record kept throughout semester by instructor

honorCode.standard: Students expected to be honest in all academic work
honorCode.definition: Work presented as your own must in fact be your own work, not another's
honorCode.violation: May result in failing grade and additional university disciplinary action
honorCode.dressAndGrooming: Expected to adhere to BYU Dress and Grooming Standards
honorCode.standards: Adherence demonstrates respect for yourself and others and ensures effective learning environment

sexualDiscrimination.prohibition: Sexual discrimination or harassment (including student-to-student) prohibited by law and BYU policy
sexualDiscrimination.reporting: Bring concerns to professor or lodge complaint with Equal Employment Office (D-240C ASB) or Honor Code Office

disability.process: Can evaluate disability and assist professor in arranging reasonable accommodations

policies.bYUMission: Assist individuals in their quest for perfection and eternal life; develop students of faith, intellect, and character with skills and desire to continue learning and serve others

officeHours.purpose: Available for questions on all coursework
officeHours.readiness: If preceded by reasonable personal effort, requests for help always cordially received by professor and TA
